key_insight: This author-correction accompanies work showing that combining coding-theory designs with deep learning models of biochemical noise yields a more scalable and robust DNA data-storage pipeline — i.e., learned decoders plus DNA-aware error-correcting codes improve reliability of storage and retrieval.
problem_solved: Overcomes high, complex error rates and scalability limits in DNA-based storage systems by jointly addressing biochemical constraints, error correction, and data-driven noise modeling for accurate large-scale encoding and decoding.
method: Apply coding-theory-based encoders/decoders tailored to DNA constraints (sequence composition, run-length limits) to provide strong error correction.
Train deep learning models to characterize and invert synthesis/sequencing noise, guiding or replacing parts of the decoding process.
Integrate code design and learned decoders into a system-level pipeline that is optimized for scalability and practical biochemical constraints.
impact: Illustrates a practical, cross-disciplinary template where ML models of physical noise plug into information-theoretic code design — valuable for ML practitioners interested in real-world noisy channels, robust model deployment, and bio-digital storage applications.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: encoding → DNA synthesis → noisy channel (sequencing) → learned decoder + error-correcting code → recovered data
Schematic showing how coding constraints (GC content, homopolymers) and error types (substitutions/indels) are handled
Performance chart comparing retrieval accuracy / error rate vs. prior methods and scale (# bases stored)
Icon set: DNA strand, neural network, error-correcting code (parity/check matrix), and scalability arrow
paper_title: Author Correction: Scalable and robust DNA-based storage via coding theory and deep learning
paper_authors: Daniella Bar-Lev, Itai Orr, Omer Sabary, Tuvi Etzion, Eitan Yaakobi
